<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<h4 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item 8.01.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Other Events.</font></b></h4>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Filed as part of this Current Report on Form 8-K are
the consolidated balance sheets of Kraft Foods Inc. and subsidiaries as of
December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, and the related consolidated statements of
earnings, stockholders&#146; equity and cash flows for each of the three years in
the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 (the &#147;Financial Statements&#148;), the
independent registered public accounting firm&#146;s report thereon and the
statement regarding computation of ratios of earnings to fixed charges.&nbsp;
The Financial Statements and the independent registered public accounting firm&#146;s
report will be incorporated by reference in Kraft Foods Inc.&#146;s Annual Report on
Form 10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006.</font></p>

<h4 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item 9.01.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Financial Statements
and Exhibits.</font></b></h4>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Financial Statements, together with the
independent registered public accounting firm&#146;s report thereon, are included
herein.</font></p>

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">99.2</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="86%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:86.44%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Report of management on internal control over
  financial reporting.</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="4%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:4.64%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="3%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:3.2%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="5%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:5.7%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="86%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:86.44%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="4%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:4.64%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="3%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:3.2%;">

  </td>
  <td width="86%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:86.44%;">

  firm.</font></p>

<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="right" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:right;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Exhibit
23</font></b></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">CONSENT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED
PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM</font></b></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 9.0pt 12.0pt 0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We hereby consent to the incorporation by reference in the Registration
Statements on Form S-8 (Nos. 333-71266,<br>
333-84616, 333-125992, 333-133559 and 333-137021) and on Form S-3 (Nos. 333-67770,
333-86478, 333-101829 and 333-113620) of Kraft Foods Inc., of our report dated February 5, 2007 relating to the
consolidated financial statements, management&#146;s assessment of the effectiveness
of internal control over financial reporting and the effectiveness of internal
control over financial reporting of Kraft Foods Inc., which appears in this
Current Report on Form 8-K of Kraft Foods Inc. dated February 5, 2007</font>.</p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(in millions of dollars)</font></p>

  <td width="80%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:80.94%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Class A common

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC. and
SUBSIDIARIES<br>
CONSOLIDATED STATEMENTS of EARNINGS<br>
for the years ended December 31,</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(in millions of
dollars, except per share data)</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="border-collapse:collapse;width:100.0%;">
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="72%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:72.24%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="6%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:6.76%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">2006</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC. and
SUBSIDIARIES<br>
</font>CONSOLIDATED STATEMENTS of SHAREHOLDERS&#146; EQUITY<br>
(in millions of dollars, except per share data)</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="border-collapse:collapse;width:100.0%;">
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="32%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:32.1%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:6.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:.34%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:6.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>

  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:6.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.2%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:6.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="7%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:7.32%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:6.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.2%;">

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">3,060</font></p>

for the years ended December 31,</font></p>

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;font-style:italic;">&nbsp;</font></i></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;font-style:italic;">&nbsp;</font></i></p>

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC. and
SUBSIDIARIES<br>
NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Note 1.&#160; Background and Basis of Presentation:</font></u></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-indent:9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Background:</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Kraft Foods Inc. (&#147;Kraft&#148;)
was incorporated in 2000 in the Commonwealth of Virginia.&#160; Kraft, through its subsidiaries (Kraft and
its subsidiaries are hereinafter referred to as the &#147;Company&#148;), is engaged in
the manufacture and sale of packaged foods and beverages in the United States,
Canada, Europe, Latin America, Asia Pacific and Middle East and Africa.&#160; </font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Prior to June 13,
2001, the Company was a wholly-owned subsidiary of Altria Group, Inc.&#160; On June 13, 2001, the Company completed an
initial public offering (&#147;IPO&#148;) of 280,000,000 shares of its Class A common
stock at a price of $31.00 per share.&#160; At
December 31, 2006, Altria Group, Inc. held 98.5% of the combined voting power
of the Company&#146;s outstanding capital stock and owned 89.0% of the outstanding
shares of the Company&#146;s capital stock.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As further
discussed in Note 20. <i>Subsequent Event</i>,
on January 31, 2007, Altria Group, Inc.&#146;s Board of Directors approved a
tax-free distribution to its stockholders of all of its interest in the
Company.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In June 2005, the
Company sold substantially all of its sugar confectionery business for pre-tax
proceeds of approximately $1.4 billion.&#160;
The Company has reflected the results of its sugar confectionery
business prior to the closing date as discontinued operations on the
consolidated statements of earnings.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In October 2005,
the Company announced that, effective January 1, 2006, its Canadian business
would be realigned to better integrate it into the Company&#146;s North American
business by product category.&#160; Beginning
in the first quarter of 2006, the operating results of the Canadian business
were being reported throughout the North American food segments.&#160; In addition, in the first quarter of 2006,
the Company&#146;s international businesses were realigned to reflect the
reorganization announced within Europe in November 2005.&#160; The two revised international segments, which
are reflected in these consolidated financial statements and notes, are
European Union; and Developing Markets, Oceania &amp; North Asia, the latter to
reflect the Company&#146;s increased management focus on developing markets.&#160; Accordingly, prior period segment results
have been restated.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Basis of
presentation:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The consolidated
financial statements include Kraft, as well as its wholly-owned and
majority-owned subsidiaries.&#160; Investments
in which the Company exercises significant influence (20% - 50% ownership
interest) are accounted for under the equity method of accounting.&#160; Investments in which the Company has an
ownership interest of less than 20%, or does not exercise significant
influence, are accounted for by the cost method of accounting.&#160; All intercompany transactions and balances
between and among Kraft&#146;s subsidiaries have been eliminated.&#160; Transactions between any of the Company&#146;s
businesses and Altria Group, Inc. and its affiliates are included in these
financial statements.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The preparation of
financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates
and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, the
disclosure of contingent liabilities at the dates of the financial statements
and the reported amounts of net revenues and expenses during the reporting
periods.&#160; Significant estimates and
assumptions include, among other things, pension and benefit plan assumptions,
lives and valuation assumptions of goodwill and other intangible assets,
marketing programs and income taxes.&#160;
Actual results could differ from those estimates.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s
operating subsidiaries generally report year-end results as of the Saturday
closest to the end of each year.&#160; This
resulted in fifty-three weeks of operating results in the Company&#146;s
consolidated statement of earnings for the year ended December 31, 2005, versus
fifty-two weeks for the years ended December 31, 2006 and 2004.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">7</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='7',FILE='C:\fc\3320212955_D11365_1669637\3021-3-mo-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb  2 20:21 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC.
and SUBSIDIARIES<br>
NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Classification of
certain prior year balance sheet amounts related to pension plans have been
reclassified to conform with the current year&#146;s presentation.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Note 2.&#160; Summary of Significant Accounting Policies:</font></u></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 27.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Cash and cash equivalents:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Cash equivalents
include demand deposits with banks and all highly liquid investments with
original maturities of three months or less.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 27.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Depreciation,
amortization and goodwill valuation:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Property, plant
and equipment are stated at historical cost and depreciated by the
straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets.&#160; Machinery and equipment are depreciated over
periods ranging from 3 to 20 years, and buildings and building improvements
over periods up to 40 years.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Definite life
intangible assets are amortized over their estimated useful lives.&#160; The Company is required to conduct an annual
review of goodwill and intangible assets for potential impairment.&#160; Goodwill impairment testing requires a
comparison between the carrying value and fair value of each reporting
unit.&#160; If the carrying value exceeds the
fair value, goodwill is considered impaired.&#160;
The amount of impairment loss is measured as the difference between the
carrying value and implied fair value of goodwill, which is determined using
discounted cash flows.&#160; Impairment
testing for non-amortizable intangible assets requires a comparison between the
fair value and carrying value of the intangible asset.&#160; If the carrying value exceeds fair value, the
intangible asset is considered impaired and is reduced to fair value.&#160; During the first quarter of 2006, the Company
completed its annual review of goodwill and intangible assets and recorded
non-cash pre-tax charges of $24 million related to an intangible asset
impairment for biscuits assets in Egypt and hot cereal assets in the United
States.&#160; Additionally, in 2006, as part
of the sale of its pet snacks brand and assets, the Company recorded non-cash
pre-tax asset impairment charges of $86 million, which included the write-off
of a portion of the associated goodwill and intangible assets of $25 million
and $55 million, respectively, as well as $6 million of asset write-downs.&#160; In January 2007, the Company announced the
sale of its hot cereal assets and trademarks.&#160;
In recognition of the anticipated sale, the Company recorded a pre-tax
asset impairment charge of $69 million in 2006 for these assets, which included
the write-off of a portion of the associated goodwill and intangible assets of
$15 million and $52 million, respectively, as well as $2 million of asset
write-downs.&#160; During the first quarter of
2005, the Company completed its annual review of goodwill and intangible assets
and no impairment charges resulted from this review.&#160; However, as part of the sale of certain Canadian
assets and two brands, the Company recorded total non-cash pre-tax asset
impairment charges of $269 million in 2005, which included impairment of
goodwill and intangible assets of $13 million and $118 million, respectively,
as well as $138 million of asset write-downs.&#160;
</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">8</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

and SUBSIDIARIES<br>
NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At December 31,
2006 and 2005, goodwill by reportable segment was as follows (in millions):</font></p>

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Non-amortizable
intangible assets consist substantially of brand names purchased through the
Nabisco acquisition.&#160; Amortizable
intangible assets consist primarily of certain trademark licenses and
non-compete agreements.&#160; Amortization
expense for intangible assets was $7 million, $10 million and $11 million for
the years ended December 31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively.&#160; Amortization expense for each of the next
five years is currently estimated to be approximately $10 million or less.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The movement in
goodwill and gross carrying amount of intangible assets is as follows:</font></p>

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="7" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:5.0pt;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="41" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:30.85pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">25,553</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="7" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:5.0pt;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="41" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:30.85pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">

  <td width="41" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:30.85pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">24,648</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">

</table>

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The increase in
goodwill and intangible assets from acquisitions is related to preliminary
allocations of purchase price for the Company&#146;s acquisition of certain United
Biscuits operations and Nabisco trademarks as discussed in Note 6. <i>Acquisitions</i>.&#160; The
allocations are based upon preliminary estimates and assumptions and are
subject to revision when appraisals are finalized, which is expected to occur
during the first half of 2007.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">9</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='9',FILE='C:\fc\3320212955_D11365_1669637\3021-3-mo-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb  2 20:21 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC.
and SUBSIDIARIES<br>
NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Environmental
costs:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company is
subject to laws and regulations relating to the protection of the
environment.&#160; The Company provides for
expenses associated with environmental remediation obligations on an
undiscounted basis when such amounts are probable and can be reasonably
estimated.&#160; Such accruals are adjusted as
new information develops or circumstances change.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">While it is not
possible to quantify with certainty the potential impact of actions regarding
environmental remediation and compliance efforts that the Company may undertake
in the future, in the opinion of management, environmental remediation and
compliance costs, before taking into account any recoveries from third parties,
will not have a material adverse effect on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial
position, results of operations or cash flows.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Foreign currency
translation:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company
translates the results of operations of its foreign subsidiaries using average
exchange rates during each period, whereas balance sheet accounts are
translated using exchange rates at the end of each period.&#160; Currency translation adjustments are recorded
as a component of shareholders&#146; equity.&#160;
Transaction gains and losses are recorded in the consolidated statements
of earnings and were not significant for any of the periods presented.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Guarantees:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company accounts for guarantees in accordance with Financial
Accounting Standards Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) Interpretation No. 45, &#147;Guarantor&#146;s
Accounting and Disclosure Requirements for Guarantees, Including Indirect
Guarantees of Indebtedness of Others.&#148;&#160;
Interpretation No. 45 requires the disclosure of certain guarantees and
the recognition of a liability for the fair value of the obligation of
qualifying guarantee activities.&#160; See
Note 18.&#160; <i>Contingencies</i> for a further discussion of guarantees.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Hedging
instruments:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Derivative
financial instruments are recorded at fair value on the consolidated balance
sheets as either assets or liabilities.&#160;
Changes in the fair value of derivatives are recorded each period either
in accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) or in earnings, depending
on whether a derivative is designated and effective as part of a hedge
transaction and, if it is, the type of hedge transaction.&#160; Gains and losses on derivative instruments
reported in accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) are reclassified
to the consolidated statement of earnings in the periods in which operating
results are affected by the hedged item.&#160;
Cash flows from hedging instruments are classified in the same manner as
the affected hedged item in the consolidated statements of cash flows.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Impairment of
long-lived assets:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company
reviews long-lived assets, including amortizable intangible assets, for
impairment whenever events or changes in business circumstances indicate that
the carrying amount of the assets may not be fully recoverable.&#160; The Company performs undiscounted operating
cash flow analyses to determine if an impairment exists.&#160; For purposes of recognition and measurement
of an impairment for assets held for use, the Company groups assets and
liabilities at the lowest level for which cash flows are separately
identifiable.&#160; If an impairment is
determined to exist, any related impairment loss is calculated based on fair
value.&#160; Impairment losses on assets to be
disposed of, if any, are based on the estimated proceeds to be received, less
costs of disposal.&#160; During 2006, the
Company recorded non-cash pre-tax asset impairment charges of $245 million related
to its <i>Tassimo</i> hot beverage business.&#160; The charges are included in asset impairment
and exit costs in the consolidated statement of earnings.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">10</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='10',FILE='C:\fc\3320212955_D11365_1669637\3021-3-mo-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb  2 20:21 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC.
and SUBSIDIARIES<br>
NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Income taxes:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company
accounts for income taxes in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting
Standards (&#147;SFAS&#148;) No. 109, &#147;Accounting for Income Taxes.&#148;&#160; The U.S. accounts of the Company are included
in the consolidated federal income tax return of Altria Group, Inc.&#160; Income taxes are generally computed on a
separate company basis.&#160; To the extent
that foreign tax credits, capital losses and other credits generated by the
Company, which cannot currently be utilized on a separate company basis, are
utilized in Altria Group, Inc.&#146;s consolidated federal income tax return, the
benefit is recognized in the calculation of the Company&#146;s provision for income
taxes.&#160; Based on the Company&#146;s current
estimate, this benefit is calculated to be approximately $195 million, $225
million and $70 million for the years ended December 31, 2006, 2005 and 2004,
respectively.&#160; The amounts in 2005 and
2006 include dividend repatriations and the impact of certain legal entity
reorganizations.&#160; The Company makes
payments to, or is reimbursed by, Altria Group, Inc. for the tax effects
resulting from its inclusion in Altria Group, Inc.&#146;s consolidated federal
income tax return, including current taxes payable and net changes in tax
provisions.&#160; The Company is assessing
opportunities to mitigate the loss of tax benefits upon Altria Group, Inc.&#146;s
distribution of its Kraft shares, and currently estimates the annual amount of
lost tax benefits to be in the range of $50 million to $75 million.&#160; Significant judgment is required in
determining income tax provisions and in evaluating tax positions.&#160; The Company establishes additional provisions
for income taxes when, despite the belief that existing tax positions are fully
supportable, there remain certain positions that are likely to be challenged
and that may not be sustained on review by tax authorities.&#160; The Company evaluates and potentially adjusts
these provisions in light of changing facts and circumstances.&#160; The consolidated tax provision includes the
impact of changes to accruals that are deemed necessary.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In July 2006, the FASB
issued FASB Interpretation No. 48, &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes
- - an interpretation of FASB Statement No. 109&#148; (&#147;FIN 48&#148;), which will become
effective for the Company on January 1, 2007.&#160;
The Interpretation prescribes a recognition threshold and a measurement
attribute for the financial statement recognition and measurement of tax
positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.&#160; For those benefits to be recognized, a tax
position must be more-likely-than-not to be sustained upon examination by
taxing authorities.&#160; The amount
recognized is measured as the largest amount of benefit that is greater than 50
percent likely of being realized upon ultimate settlement.&#160; The adoption of FIN 48 will result in an
increase to shareholders&#146; equity as of January 1, 2007 of approximately $200
million to $225 million.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 27.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Inventories:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Inventories are
stated at the lower of cost or market.&#160;
The last-in, first-out (&#147;LIFO&#148;) method is used to cost a majority of
domestic inventories.&#160; The cost of other
inventories is principally determined by the average cost method. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company
adopted the provisions of SFAS No. 151, &#147;Inventory Costs&#148; prospectively as of
January 1, 2006.&#160; SFAS No. 151 requires
that abnormal idle facility expense, spoilage, freight and handling costs be
recognized as current-period charges.&#160; In
addition, SFAS No. 151 requires that allocation of fixed production overhead
costs to inventories be based on the normal capacity of the production
facility.&#160; The effect of adoption did not
have a material impact on the Company&#146;s consolidated results of operations,
financial position or cash flows. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Marketing costs:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company
promotes its products with advertising, consumer incentives and trade
promotions.&#160; Such programs include, but
are not limited to, discounts, coupons, rebates, in-store display incentives
and volume-based incentives.&#160; Advertising
costs are expensed as incurred.&#160; </font>Consumer incentive and trade promotion
activities are recorded as a reduction of revenues based on amounts estimated
as being due to customers and consumers at the end of a period, based
principally on historical utilization and redemption rates.&#160; For interim reporting purposes, advertising
and consumer incentive expenses are charged to operations as a percentage of
volume, based on estimated volume and related expense for the full year.</p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">11</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='11',FILE='C:\fc\3320212955_D11365_1669637\3021-3-mo-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb  2 20:21 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC.
and SUBSIDIARIES<br>
NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Revenue
recognition:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company
recognizes revenues, net of sales incentives and including shipping and handling
charges billed to customers, upon shipment or delivery of goods when title and
risk of loss pass to customers.&#160; Shipping
and handling costs are classified as part of cost of sales.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Software costs:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company
capitalizes certain computer software and software development costs incurred
in connection with developing or obtaining computer software for internal
use.&#160; Capitalized software costs are
included in property, plant and equipment on the consolidated balance sheets
and amortized on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the
software, which do not exceed five years.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Stock-based
compensation:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Effective January 1, 2006, the Company adopted the provisions of SFAS
No. 123 (Revised 2004), &#147;Share-Based Payment,&#148; (&#147;SFAS No. 123(R)&#148;) using the
modified prospective method, which requires measurement of compensation cost
for all stock-based awards at fair value on date of grant and recognition of
compensation over the service periods for awards expected to vest.&#160; The fair value of restricted stock and rights
to receive shares of stock is determined based on the number of shares granted
and the market value at date of grant.&#160;
The fair value of stock options is determined using a modified
Black-Scholes methodology.&#160; The impact of
adoption was not material.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 31.3pt;text-indent:-16.3pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The adoption of SFAS No.
123(R) resulted in a cumulative effect gain of $6 million, which is net of $3
million in taxes, in the consolidated statement of earnings for the year ended
December 31, 2006.&#160; This gain resulted
from the impact of estimating future forfeitures on restricted stock and rights
to receive shares of stock in the determination of periodic expense for
unvested awards, rather than recording forfeitures only when they occur.&#160; The gross cumulative effect was recorded in
marketing, administration and research costs for the year ended December 31,
2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 31.3pt;text-indent:-16.3pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company previously
applied the recognition and measurement principles of Accounting Principles
Board Opinion No. 25, &#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees,&#148; (&#147;APB 25&#148;)
and provided the pro forma disclosures required by SFAS No. 123, &#147;Accounting
for Stock-Based Compensation&#148; (&#147;SFAS No. 123&#148;). No compensation expense for
employee stock options was reflected in net earnings in 2005 and 2004, as all
stock options granted under those plans had an exercise price equal to the
market value of the common stock on the date of the grant.&#160; Historical consolidated statements of
earnings already include the compensation expense for restricted stock and rights
to receive shares of stock.&#160; The following
table illustrates the effect on net earnings and earnings per share (&#147;EPS&#148;) if
the Company had applied the fair value recognition provisions of SFAS No. 123
to measure compensation expense for stock option awards for the years ended
December 31, 2005 and 2004 (in millions, except per share data):</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">12</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company elected to calculate the initial pool of tax benefits
resulting from tax deductions in excess of the stock-based employee compensation
expense recognized in the statement of earnings under FASB Staff Position
123(R)-3, &#147;Transition Election Related to Accounting for the Tax Effects of
Share-Based Payment Awards.&#148;&#160; Under SFAS
No. 123(R), tax shortfalls occur when actual tax deductible compensation
expense is less than cumulative stock-based compensation expense recognized in
the financial statements.&#160; Tax shortfalls
of $8 million were recognized for the year ended December 31, 2006, and were
recorded in additional paid-in capital.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Note 3.&#160; Asset Impairment, Exit and Implementation
Costs:</font></u></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Restructuring Program:</font></i></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 31.15pt;text-indent:-16.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">In
January&nbsp;2004, the Company announced a three-year restructuring program
with the objectives of leveraging the Company&#146;s global scale, realigning and
lowering its cost structure, and optimizing capacity utilization.&#160; I</font>n January 2006, the Company announced plans to expand its restructuring
efforts through 2008.&#160; The entire
restructuring program is expected to result in $3.0 billion in pre-tax charges
reflecting asset disposals, severance and implementation costs.&#160; The decline of $700 million from the $3.7
billion in pre-tax charges previously announced was due primarily to lower than
projected severance costs, the cancellation of an initiative to generate sales
efficiencies, and the sale of one plant that was originally planned to be
closed.&#160; As part of this program, the
Company anticipates the closure of up to 40 facilities and the elimination of
approximately 14,000 positions.&#160;
Approximately $1.9 billion of the $3.0 billion in pre-tax charges are
expected to require cash payments.&#160; P<font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">re-tax restructuring program charges</font>,
including implementation costs<font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;"> for the years
ended December 31, 2006, 2005 and 2004 were $673 million, $297 million and $641
million, respectively.&#160; Total pre-tax restructuring
charges incurred since the inception of the program in January 2004 were $1.6
billion.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 31.3pt;text-indent:-16.3pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2006, the Company
announced a seven-year, $1.7 billion agreement to receive information
technology services from Electronic Data Systems (&#147;EDS&#148;).&#160; The agreement, which includes data centers,
web hosting, telecommunications and IT workplace services, began on June 1,
2006.&#160; Pursuant to the agreement,
approximately 670 employees, who provided certain IT support to the Company,
were transitioned to EDS.&#160; As a result of
the agreement, in 2006 the Company incurred pre-tax asset impairment and exit
costs of $51 million and implementation costs of $56 million related to the
transition.&#160; These costs were included in
the pre-tax restructuring program charges discussed above.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">13</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='13',FILE='C:\fc\3320212955_D11365_1669637\3021-3-mo-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb  2 20:21 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC.
and SUBSIDIARIES<br>
NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Restructuring Costs:</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.7pt;text-indent:-27.35pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2006, 2005 and
2004, pre-tax charges under the restructuring program of $578 million, $210
million and $583 million, respectively, were recorded as asset impairment and
exit costs on the consolidated statements of earnings.&#160; These pre-tax charges resulted from the
announcement of the closing of 27 plants since January 2004, of which 8 occurred
in 2006, the continuation of a number of workforce reduction programs, and the
termination of co-manufacturing agreements in 2004.&#160; Approximately $332 million of the pre-tax
charges incurred during 2006 will require cash payments.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Pre-tax
restructuring liability activity for the years ended December 31, 2006 and
2005, was as follows:</font></p>

<div align="center" style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">)</font></p>

  <td width="60" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:45.15pt;">

  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="54" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:40.15pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">197</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="6" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:4.15pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Severance costs in
the above schedule, which relate to the workforce reduction programs, include
the cost of related benefits.&#160; Specific
programs announced since 2004, as part of the overall restructuring program,
will result in the elimination of approximately 9,800 positions.&#160; At December 31, 2006, approximately 8,400 of
these positions have been eliminated.&#160;
Asset write-downs relate to the impairment of assets caused by the plant
closings and related activity.&#160; Other
costs incurred relate primarily to contract termination costs associated with
the plant closings and the termination of leasing agreements.&#160; Severance costs taken against assets relate
to incremental pension costs, which reduce prepaid pension assets.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 24.3pt 12.0pt 0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Implementation
Costs:</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2006, 2005
and 2004, the Company recorded pre-tax implementation costs associated with the
restructuring program.&#160; These costs
include the discontinuance of certain product lines and incremental costs
related to the integration and streamlining of functions and closure of
facilities.&#160; Substantially all
implementation costs incurred in 2006 will require cash payments.&#160; These costs were recorded on the consolidated
statements of earnings as follows:</font></p>

<div align="center" style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC.
and SUBSIDIARIES<br>
NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 24.3pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-36.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Asset
Impairment Charges:</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 32.0pt;text-indent:-24.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2006, the
Company sold its pet snacks brand and assets, and recorded tax expense of $57
million and incurred a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $86 million in 2006
in recognition of this sale.&#160; In January
2007, the Company announced the sale of its hot cereal assets and
trademarks.&#160; In recognition of the
anticipated sale, the Company recorded a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $69
million in 2006 for these assets.&#160; These
pre-tax asset impairment charges, which included the write-off of a portion of
the associated goodwill, and intangible and fixed assets, were recorded as
asset impairment and exit costs on the consolidated statement of earnings.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2006, the
Company completed its annual review of goodwill and intangible assets, and
recorded non-cash pre-tax charges of $24 million related to an intangible asset
impairment for biscuits assets in Egypt and hot cereal assets in the United
States.&#160; Also during 2006, the Company
re-evaluated the business model for its <i>Tassimo</i> hot
beverage system, the revenues of which lagged the Company&#146;s projections.&#160; This evaluation resulted in a $245 million
non-cash pre-tax asset impairment charge related to lower utilization of
existing manufacturing capacity.&#160; These
charges were recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the consolidated
statement of earnings.&#160; In addition, the
Company anticipates that the impairment will result in related cash
expenditures of approximately $3 million, primarily related to decommissioning
of idle production lines.&#160; During 2005,
the Company completed its annual review of goodwill and intangible assets and
no charges resulted from this review.&#160;
During 2004, the Company recorded a $29 million non-cash pre-tax charge
related to an intangible asset impairment for a small confectionery business in
the United States and certain brands in Mexico.&#160;
A portion of this charge, $17 million, was reclassified to earnings from
discontinued operations on the consolidated statement of earnings in the fourth
quarter of 2004.&#160; The remaining charge
was recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the consolidated statement
of earnings.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2005, the
Company sold its fruit snacks assets and incurred a pre-tax asset impairment
charge of $93 million in recognition of the sale.&#160; During December 2005, the Company reached
agreements to sell certain assets in Canada and a small biscuit brand in the United
States and incurred pre-tax asset impairment charges of $176 million in
recognition of these sales.&#160; These
transactions closed in 2006.&#160; These
charges, which included the write-off of all associated intangible assets, were
recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the consolidated statement of
earnings.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In November 2004,
following discussions with the Company&#146;s joint venture partner in Turkey and an
independent valuation of its equity investment, it was determined that a
permanent decline in value had occurred. This valuation resulted in a $47
million non-cash pre-tax charge.&#160; This
charge was recorded as marketing, administration and research costs on the
consolidated statement of earnings.&#160; During
2005, the Company&#146;s interest in the joint venture was sold.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In June 2005, the
Company sold substantially all of its sugar confectionery business for
approximately $1.4 billion.&#160; In 2004, as
a result of the anticipated transaction, the Company recorded non-cash asset
impairments totaling $107 million.&#160; These
charges were included in loss from discontinued operations on the consolidated
statement of earnings.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In December 2004,
the Company announced the sale of its U.S. yogurt assets, which closed in the first
quarter of 2005.&#160; In 2004, as a result of
the anticipated transaction, the Company recorded asset impairments totaling $8
million.&#160; This charge was recorded as
asset impairment and exit costs on the consolidated statement of earnings.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">15</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='15',FILE='C:\fc\3320212955_D11365_1669637\3021-3-mo-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb  2 20:21 2007' -->

and SUBSIDIARIES<br>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-36.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Total:</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The pre-tax asset
impairment, exit and implementation costs discussed above, for the years ended
December 31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, were included in the operating companies
income of the following segments:</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="7" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:5.0pt;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="67" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:50.4pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">1,097</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC.
and SUBSIDIARIES<br>
NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:.98%;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="9%" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:9.96%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">832</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:.34%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 16.3pt;text-indent:-16.3pt;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Note 4.&#160; Related Party Transactions:</font></u></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Altria Group, Inc.&#146;s
subsidiary, Altria Corporate Services, Inc., provides the Company with various
services, including planning, legal, treasury, auditing, insurance, human
resources, office of the secretary, corporate affairs, information technology,
aviation and tax services.&#160; Billings for
these services, which were based on the cost to Altria Corporate Services, Inc.
to provide such services and a 5% management fee based on wages and benefits,
were $178 million, $237 million and $310 million for the years ended December
31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively.&#160;
The Company performed at a similar cost various functions in 2006 and
2005 that previously had been provided by Altria Corporate Services, Inc.,
resulting in lower service charges in 2006 and 2005.&#160; The Company plans to undertake all remaining
services currently provided by Altria Corporate Services, Inc. at a similar
cost in 2007.&#160; These costs were paid to
Altria Corporate Services, Inc. monthly.&#160;
Although the cost of these services cannot be quantified on a
stand-alone basis, management has assessed that the billings are reasonable
based on the level of support provided by Altria Corporate Services, Inc., and
that they reflect all services provided.&#160;
The cost and nature of the services are reviewed annually by the Company&#146;s
Audit Committee, which is comprised of independent directors.&#160; The effects of these transactions are
included in operating cash flows in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of
cash flows. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2006, the
Company purchased certain real estate and personal property located in Wilkes
Barre, Pennsylvania, from Altria Corporate Services, Inc., for an aggregate
purchase price of $9.3 million.&#160; In
addition, the Company assumed all of Altria Corporate Services, Inc.&#146;s rights
under a lease for certain real property located in San Antonio, Texas.&#160; The Company also purchased certain personal
property located in San Antonio, Texas from Altria Corporate Services, Inc.,
for an aggregate purchase price of $6.0 million. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Also, see Note 13.
<i>Income Taxes</i> regarding the favorable
impact to the Company of the closure of an Internal Revenue Service review of
Altria Group, Inc.&#146;s consolidated federal income tax return recorded during
2006. </font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">17</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='17',FILE='C:\fc\33214559106_D11113_1669854\3021-3-mo-05.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb  2 21:46 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC.
and SUBSIDIARIES<br>
NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2005, the
Company repatriated certain foreign earnings as part of Altria Group, Inc.&#146;s
dividend repatriation plan under provisions of the American Jobs Creation
Act.&#160; Increased taxes for this
repatriation of $21 million were reimbursed by Altria Group, Inc.&#160; The reimbursement was reported in the Company&#146;s
financial statements as an increase to additional paid-in capital. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In December 2005,
the Company purchased an airport hangar and certain personal property located
at the hangar in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, from Altria Corporate Services, Inc. for
an aggregate purchase price of approximately $3.3 million.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In December 2004,
the Company purchased two corporate aircraft from Altria Corporate Services,
Inc. for an aggregate purchase price of approximately $47 million.&#160; The Company also entered into an Aircraft
Management Agreement with Altria Corporate Services, Inc. in December 2004,
pursuant to which Altria Corporate Services, Inc. agreed to perform aircraft
management, pilot services, maintenance and other aviation services for the
Company.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At December 31,
2006 and 2005, the Company had short-term amounts payable to Altria Group, Inc.
of $607 million and $652 million, respectively.&#160;
The amounts payable to Altria Group, Inc. generally include accrued
dividends, taxes and service fees.&#160; Interest
on intercompany borrowings is based on the applicable London Interbank Offered
Rate.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The fair values of
the Company&#146;s short-term amounts due to Altria Group, Inc. and affiliates
approximate carrying amounts.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 27.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Note 5.&#160; Divestitures:</font></u></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Discontinued
Operations:</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In June 2005, the
Company sold substantially all of its sugar confectionery business for pre-tax
proceeds of approximately $1.4 billion.&#160;
The sale included the <i>Life Savers</i>, <i>Creme Savers</i>, <i>Altoids</i>, <i>Trolli</i> and <i>Sugus</i>
brands.&#160; The Company has reflected the
results of its sugar confectionery business prior to the closing date as discontinued
operations on the consolidated statements of earnings.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Summary results of
operations for the sugar confectionery business were as follows:</font></p>

  </td>

 <tr bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="262" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:196.4pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Provision for
  income taxes</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="80" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:60.35pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">

  </td>

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The loss on sale
of discontinued operations, above, for the year ended December 31, 2005,
related largely to taxes on the transaction.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">18</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='18',FILE='C:\fc\33214559106_D11113_1669854\3021-3-mo-05.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb  2 21:46 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC.
and SUBSIDIARIES<br>
NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Other:</font></i></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During</font>&nbsp;2006, the Company sold its rice
brand and assets, and its industrial coconut assets.&#160; The Company also sold its pet snacks brand
and assets in 2006 and recorded tax expense of $57 million related to the sale.&#160; In addition, the Company incurred a pre-tax
asset impairment charge of $86 million in 2006 in recognition of this
sale.&#160; Additionally, during 2006, the Company sold certain Canadian assets and
a small U.S. biscuit brand, and incurred pre-tax asset impairment charges of
$176 million in 2005 in recognition of these sales.&#160; Also during 2006, the Company sold a U.S.
coffee plant.&#160; The aggregate proceeds
received from these sales were $946 million, on which the Company recorded
pre-tax gains of $117 million.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2005, the Company sold its fruit snacks assets, and incurred a
pre-tax asset impairment charge of $93 million in recognition of this
sale.&#160; Additionally, during 2005, the
Company sold its U.K. desserts assets, its U.S. yogurt assets, a small business
in Colombia, a minor trademark in Mexico and a small equity investment in
Turkey.&#160; The aggregate proceeds</font> </font>received from these sales were $238 million,
on which the Company recorded pre-tax gains of $108 million.&#160;</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2004, the
Company sold a Brazilian snack nuts business and trademarks associated with a
candy business in Norway.&#160; The aggregate
proceeds received from the sale of these businesses were $18 million, on which
pre-tax losses of $3 million were recorded.&#160;
</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The operating
results of the other divestitures, discussed above, in the aggregate, were not
material to the Company&#146;s consolidated financial position, results of
operations or cash flows in any of the periods presented.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 27.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Note 6.&#160; Acquisitions:</font></u></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">United
Biscuits: </font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In September 2006, the Company acquired the Spanish and Portuguese
operations of United Biscuits (&#147;UB&#148;) and rights to all Nabisco trademarks in
the European Union, Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Africa, which UB has
held since 2000, for a total cost of approximately $1.1 billion.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Spanish and Portuguese operations of UB include its biscuits, dry
desserts, canned meats, tomato and fruit juice businesses as well as seven
manufacturing facilities and 1,300 employees.&#160;
From September 2006 to December 31, 2006, these businesses contributed
net revenues of approximately $111 million. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The non-cash acquisition was financed by the Company&#146;s assumption of
approximately $541 million of debt issued by the acquired business immediately
prior to the acquisition, as well as $530 million of value for the redemption
of the Company&#146;s outstanding investment in UB, primarily deep-discount
securities.&#160; The redemption of the
Company&#146;s investment in UB resulted in a pre-tax gain on closing of
approximately $251 million ($148 million after-tax or $0.09 per diluted share).
</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Aside from the debt
assumed as part of the acquisition price, the Company acquired assets
consisting primarily of goodwill of $734 million, other intangible assets of
$217 million, property plant and equipment of $161 million, receivables of $101
million and inventories of $34 million.&#160;
These amounts represent the preliminary allocation of purchase price and
are subject to revision when appraisals are finalized, which is expected to
occur during the first half of 2007.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">19</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='19',FILE='C:\fc\33214559106_D11113_1669854\3021-3-mo-05.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb  2 21:46 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC.
and SUBSIDIARIES<br>
NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Other: </font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2004, the Company
acquired a U.S.-based beverage business for a total cost of $137 million.&#160; The effect of this acquisition was not
material to the Company&#146;s consolidated financial position, results of
operations or cash flows in any of the periods presented.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 27.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Note 7.&#160; Inventories: </font></u></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The cost of
approximately 41% and 40% of inventories in 2006 and 2005, respectively, was
determined using the LIFO method.&#160; The
stated LIFO amounts of inventories were approximately $70 million and $71
million higher than the current cost of inventories at December 31, 2006 and
2005, respectively.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 27.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Note 8.&#160; Short-Term Borrowings and Borrowing
Arrangements:</font></u></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At December 31,
2006 and 2005, the Company&#146;s short-term borrowings and related average interest
rates consisted of the following: </font></p>

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The fair values of
the Company&#146;s short-term borrowings at December 31, 2006 and 2005, based upon
current market interest rates, approximate the amounts disclosed above.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company
maintains revolving credit facilities that have historically been used to
support the issuance of commercial paper.&#160;
At December 31, 2006, the Company had a $4.5 billion, multi-year
revolving credit facility that expires in April 2010 on which no amounts were
drawn.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s revolving credit facility, which is for
its sole use, requires the maintenance of a minimum net worth of $20.0
billion.&#160; At December 31, 2006, the
Company&#146;s net worth was $28.6 billion.&#160;
The Company expects to continue to meet this covenant.&#160; The revolving credit facility does not
include any other financial tests, any credit rating triggers or any provisions
that could require the posting of collateral.&#160;
</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition to the above, certain international subsidiaries
of Kraft maintain credit lines to meet the short-term working capital needs of
the international businesses.&#160; These
credit lines, which amounted to approximately $1.1 billion as of December 31,
2006, are for the sole use of the Company&#146;s international businesses.&#160; Borrowings on these lines amounted to
approximately $200 million and $400 million at December 31, 2006 and 2005,
respectively.&#160; At December 31, 2006 the
Company also had approximately $0.3 billion of outstanding short-term debt
related to its United Biscuits acquisition discussed in Note 6. <i>Acquisitions</i>.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">20</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC.
and SUBSIDIARIES<br>
NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</font></p>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Based on market
quotes, where available, or interest rates currently available to the Company
for issuance of debt with similar terms and remaining maturities, the aggregate
fair value of the Company&#146;s long-term debt, including the current portion of
long-term debt, was $8,706 million and $9,945 million at December 31, 2006 and
2005, respectively.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">21</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">KRAFT FOODS INC.
and SUBSIDIARIES<br>
NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 27.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Note 10.&#160; Capital Stock:</font></u></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s
articles of incorporation authorize 3.0 billion shares of Class A common stock,
2.0 billion shares of Class B common stock and 500 million shares of preferred
stock.&#160; Shares of Class A common stock
issued, repurchased and outstanding were as follows:</font></p>
